Award.AwardTitle: EAGER/Collaborative Research/Cybermanufacturing: Just Make It: Integrating Cybermanufacturing into Design Studios to Enable Innovation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing, in which physical products are fabricated in a layer-by-layer fashion, is creating renewed interest in manufacturing. Additive manufacturing offers numerous advantages over traditional manufacturing processes, such as machining, casting, and forging, but it is not always the most cost effective method for fabricating parts. In many cases, subtractive manufacturing techniques (i.e., fabrication processes like machining that remove material to create a finished part) are more cost-effective, but they require additional expertise and set-up compared to the "push button" technology available on many additive manufacturing systems. In order to further improve accessibility to all digital fabrication technologies, and to better inform "makers" of the manufacturability of their designs, the team of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will create a set of design tools and software applications that provide rapid manufacturing feedback in terms of geometry, material, quality, lead time, and cost to fabricate a component. The cybermanufacturing system will be integrated into undergraduate mechanical engineering design studios at three partner institutions (Georgia Tech, Penn State University, and Virginia Tech) and will be formally assessed in order to answer the research question, "How does this cybermanufacturing system and resulting design assessment capability enable innovation?" This work will lay the foundation for future, larger-scale cybermanufacturing efforts that will connect engineering students and the broader maker community with a larger array of manufacturing capabilities and know-how, making them better prepared for the engineering and entrepreneurial workforce of tomorrow.

The project's cloud-based cybermanufacturing system will be comprised of applications (apps) for additive and subtractive manufacturing that will provide an integrated view of the semantic information needed to assess manufacturability of part designs. The cybermanufacturing system leverages state-of-the-art advances in tool path planning for multi-axis machine tools based on novel voxel-based flexible data representations for product geometry, which will further the flexibility and accessibility of subtractive manufacturing. The resulting system will be deployed in the partner institutions' vibrant, yet distinct, design studio environments that offer hands-on design/build experiences to several hundred undergraduate engineering students each year. The impact of the system on the design process will be measured directly using novel assessment instruments designed to probe salient aspects of innovation in product design and their impact on the students engaged. This project's approach will inform requirements for mapping more expansive networks and manufacturing capabilities in future cybermanufacturing service systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established a cloud-based cybermanufacturing system to facilitate design analysis for additive and subtractive manufacturing based on user input in terms of geometry, material, quality, lead time, and cost. The goal of the system was to further improve accessibility to additive and subtractive manufacturing technologies. The cloud-based system was comprised of applications to aid a user to assess part manufacturability and generate machine instructions for both additive and subtractive manufacturing processes. The primary goal of the research was to understand how this cybermanufacturing tool could affect understanding of design for manufacturing outcomes. These applications were deployed across three partner institutions — Georgia Tech, Penn State, and Virginia Tech — within undergraduate mechanical engineering design studio environments. These outcomes were measured in formal assessment instruments.

The intellectual merit of the work has stemmed from evaluation of the effects of rapid manufacturability assessment on understanding of design for manufacturing issues in an educational studio environment. The cloud-based cybermanufacturing system comprised of applications (apps) for additive and subtractive manufacturing that provided an integrated view of the information needed to assess manufacturability of part designs, including considerations for geometry, material, cost, quality, equipment, tooling, and time. The cybermanufacturing system leveraged state-of-the-art advances in tool path planning for multi-axis machine tools based on novel voxel-based flexible data representations for product geometry. Additionally, a mobile phone based application was developed and implemented for additive manufacturing capability analysis. These assessment tools were used in a series of projects in comparable design courses offered at each partner institution. The technologies were used to assess effects on understanding design for manufacturability issues for over 1000 students across these three institutions. From the test results, it was apparent that the use of these novel applications had a marked effect on students’ abilities to design parts with higher success for downstream manufacturing. These results help to inform requirements in mapping more expansive networks and manufacturing capabilities in future cybermanufacturing service systems. Finally, new scales for Education Readiness Levels (ERLs) were formalized and successfully validated as part of the project efforts.

The broader impacts of the work has included potential for increased design innovations in consumer and industrial products due to improved access to rapid, low cost manufacturing that is informed by design manufacturability assessment. The experimental classroom studies pursued in this project has informed design of effective manufacturability feedback tools for engineering classroom environments. Involvement of a small business entity in the research has provided a potential route for implementing these developments in commercial software offerings. The cybermanufacturing system has enabled novice entrepreneurs and amateur designers to understand the impact of design choices on downstream manufacturing issues in a dynamic feedback environment. In future implementations, this service layer will enable other application developers to furnish and access manufacturing apps that span the full spectrum from ideation to physical realization, giving rise to a virtual and deeply connected cybermanufacturing community. Overall, this work has laid the foundation for future, larger-scale cybermanufacturing efforts that will connect engineering students and novice makers with a broader array of manufacturing capabilities and know-how, thus making them better prepared for the engineering workforce and global marketplace of tomorrow.

Modified by: Christopher Saldana
